>>90696233
Combinations
Choose a number of terms from a list, in this case we choose two artists: {2$$artist1|artist2|artist3}
If $$ is not provided, then 1$$ is assumed.

If the chosen number of terms is greater than the available terms, then some terms will be duplicated, otherwise chosen terms will be unique. This is useful in the case of wildcards, e.g. {2$$__artist__} is equivalent to {2$$__artist__|__artist__}

A range can be provided: {1-3$$artist1|artist2|artist3}
In this case, a random number of artists between 1 and 3 is chosen.

Wildcards can be used and the joiner can also be specified: {{1-$$and$$__adjective__}}
Here, a random number between 1 and 3 words from adjective.txt will be chosen and joined together with the word 'and' instead of the default comma.

posts.name: John J. Nay*
posts.sub: Large Language Models as Corporate Lobbyists
posts.com:
ABSTRACT
We demonstrate a proof-of-concept of a large language model conducting corporate lobbying related activities. 1 An autoregressive large language model (OpenAI’s text-davinci-003) determines if proposed U.S. Congressional bills are relevant to specific public companies and provides explanations and confidence levels. For the bills the model deems as relevant, the model drafts a letter to the sponsor of the bill in an attempt to persuade the congressperson to make changes to the proposed legislation. We use hundreds of ground-truth labels of the relevance of a bill to a company to benchmark the performance of the model, which outperforms the baseline of predicting the most common outcome of irrelevance. We also benchmark the performance of the previous OpenAI GPT-3 model (text-davinci-002), which was state-of-the-art on many language tasks until text-davinci-003 was released on November 28, 2022. The performance of text-davinci-002 is worse than simply always predicting that a bill is irrelevant to a company. These results suggest that, as large language models continue to exhibit improved core natural language understanding capabilities, performance on corporate lobbying related tasks will continue to improve. We then discuss why this could be problematic for societal-AI alignment.

>And yet, the CPU market is still good for consumers. Arbitrary GPU price increases due to AMD and Nvidia price fixing.

Not the same at all. The latest cpus are 1 generation behind gpus in their manufacturing node in the case of amd and probably 2 gen behind with intel.
AMD also is using chiplets and a 2 gen old i/o die to further reduce costs.

That is completely different from a monolithic 380mm or 608mm die
Assuming 74.35% yield on a 300mm wafer, you get 65 functioning dies on a 608mm square die. Assuming $20k per wafer you have $307.69 for the raw die alone.
Not all the dies will be fully functional so
That doesn't cover assembly, memory chips, shipping, or profit margins.

30k wafer price comes out to $461.5 for the future.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90695573
>that graph just shows paying extra for faster ram is a meme
Not quite. Certain processors have their FCLK ideally bound to memory clock, older processors don't have more cache than a psp had RAM, and older Ryzen processors had their FCLK fixed to the memory clock.
Intel processors don't care a lot about memory clock, but in ryzens case this really depends on the generation, first gen Ryzen can see more than 20% more performance when using higher clocked memory, while the 5800X3d really doesn't care at all, after all it has only one die filled with cores (so no need to talk to other cores on other chiplets) and the absolutely massive 96MB L3 cache reduce the dependency in the main memory significantly.

posts.com:
>In C++, an std::vector consists of a pointer to a memory buffer (8 bytes), two size_ts for buffer size and capacity (2*8 bytes), taking up 24 bytes (and forcing a padding of up to 7 bytes on adjacent data). Even in the best case of 0 padding, we wasted 3 bytes for the pointer, and 3-6 (depending on the scenario) bytes per size_t (9-15/24 bytes wasted, 37.5%-62.5%): even for an int32 vector, using a 32-bit size already allows up to 16GiB of data in the vector, which most machines nowadays cannot even contain. When using 40-bit sizes, even maximum-sized byte vectors would not fit on any reasonable contemporary machine, and such amounts of data require a very customised application design anyway and therefore, containers should not default to such sizes. For most reasonable cases, a 5 byte pointer and two 3-byte sizes would suffice to address all memory and contain up to 16Mi elements per collection in a 11-byte vector structure. Large collections of small objects, such as pixel data in high resolution images, should use specialised containers suited for larger counts. With our 11 bytes vector, we use only slightly more than a sixth of a cache line, while a C++ vector takes up more than a third, and in the worst case, the C++ vector wastes an additional 7 bytes of padding, resulting in a footprint of up to 31 bytes (e.g. in an opt<vec<T>>), while ours remains constant at 9/11/13/15 (2/3/4/5-byte size type). Most programs could even save space on the pointer because rarely does a program need more than 4GiB of RAM. We can thus reduce the size of data structures by up to 2-4 times merely by removing constaints on type sizes and alignment. This effectively doubles the amount of cache we can use.
let's have this discussion again. Who here is willing to defend mandatory power-of-2 sizing of primitive types, as well as type-sized memory alignment? Modern x86 CPUs don't even have a noticeable performance hit from unaligned accesses anymore btw.

>>90690089
Vim allows me to simultaneously have a view on the file and operate on it. In addition, it gives me syntax highlighting, autocompletion, macros, bindings, including tools like :Termdebug or :make with :cw, and plugins for additional features.
I do occasionally use ed, especially on systems with broken terminal settings or broken vim install. I find it to work well, but vim's editing capabilities are a strict superset, and its other features can be life-saving (one example is how versatile netrw can be, it's network and archive-aware among other things).
sam -d is a capable replacement for ed, sharing 90% of the same flaws, but it's also much larger and not available by default. In broken sessions, ed is available and downloading extra packages is a big no. Hence, there's no point in using sam -d (let alone full sam).

posts.com:
>>90693868
Well, instances of Enum should
1) Be accessible as ErrorLevels.CRITICAL
2) Be immutable
3) Be the same object (since we don't need copies)
4) With a bit of modification (not shown here) they should replace underlying type (ErrorLevels.CRITICAL == 'CRITICAL'
There are also some fun features like search by name or by value (so lvl=ErrorLevels(level_name) works).

The issue is when you want some other attributes which are not part of value
One option is
class ErrorLevels
     ....
     
     @property
     def severity(self):
             return SEVERITY_LEVELS[self]

SEVERITY_LEVELS = {
     ErrorLevels.WARNING: 0,
     ....
}
But I don't like it, I want the additional attributes as part of declaration. Since Enums are immutable, you can't modify them in __init__ (a bit weird, but that's how it works).
We can use overloaded new, but it looks ugly.
So I started thinking about making syntaxic sugar to auto-assign first value in tuple as enum's actual value and all others to defined attributes. Typehints look good and are similar to existing dataclass definition.

PS: I'm sleepy and screwed up the `__new__`, it should also assign to _value_ attribute.

posts.sub: It seems XORG is not being developed much at all
posts.com:
https://www.phoronix.com/news/XServer-2022-Development-Pace

While Mesa's development has been very vibrant this year, the X.Org Server development pace has continued pulling back greatly from its late 00's and early 10's highs. This year saw just 156 commits to the xserver Git master branch, down from 331 last year and well off the highs of 2,114 as the most ever back in 2008. This jives with the downward pace over the past decade of the number of new commits continuing to slide. But it's not just on a commit basis but in overall code churn, 2022 was another low for the X.Org Server. With the 156 commits this year, there were just 3,618 lines of new code added and 888 lines removed.... Compared to last year with its 331 commits seeing 31.4k new lines and 179k lines removed.

The X.Org Server development this year on a commit basis hasn't been as low since 2003 when there were just 125 commits under their old development model and even back then meant there was +865k lines /680k lines removed across that span of commits. There hasn't been so little code churn to the X Server since 2002. This year saw commits from just 32 different email addresses, down from 48 in prior years and that number of different authors hasn't been so low since 2003 when there were just 10 recorded.

nothing wrong with the cuck cores. alder lake absolutely wiped the floor with amd in the mobile segment. they come from the simple observation that workloads either need the best performance from a few cores, or can utilize as many cores as possible. e.g. you rarely have 16 different videogames running at the same time. this architecture will ultimately likely stick and only get more extreme in the future (a few high perf cores and many-many serial ones that are useless on their own), but for desktop it seems like 3D cache is a more significant invention today, at least if you like conveyor belt simulators.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90694212
Su said AMD had no plans on pursuing big.LITTLE. There were just some rumor mill articles based on a vague patent filing a year or two ago for heterogeneous compute, but the patent didn't describe what would be considered traditional big.LITTLE core approach. AMD's patents were sort of partial cores that would only be activated for specific instructions, they weren't full independent cores.
So far it seems they are entirely content with their current approach stemming from the APU families. They have slightly newer power saving IP, they have smaller IP, slightly denser transistor libraries so they have better area efficiency. It makes more sense in terms of performance and economics. They can fab a core with a smaller final cache slice but with embedded TSV bumps to bond a cheap SRAM die on top where higher performance is required. posts.name: Anonymous

>>90677494
Optional dependency in Arch can only be installed manually and thus is always marked explicit.
This is different in Debian's apt where it can pull optional dependencies by one flag. In Arch you must install each of them manually.

efibootmgr --create --disk /dev/sdX# --part <partition #> --loader /X.efi --label "Pick a label" --verbose

efibootmgr --bootorder 000#,000#,000#,000#
or efibootmgr --bootnext 000#

If your PC can't find the EFI image on boot, which it won't if you unplug the USB, the boot entry will be automatically deleted. Boot entries are stored in NVRAM and space is limited.

What's the correct way to deal with environment variables? Currently I put it all into .bash_profile, which get's sourced on login. Evrything else is some kind of child of thay original bash process, so everything has all the necessary env vars.
But now I'm wxperimenting with running more of my system as systemd units, mainly for better keeping of logs. But in order for systemctl --user to have all my env vars, I need to import-environment, but that requireslisting every single variable I want. There's also the EnvironmentFile property for systemd units, but it doesn't exist on slices, like the app.slice that programs belong on.
>you're not supposed to have all those envirnment variables in every process
I need to at least have them in every process capable of running other programs. Most of my environment is shit to move configs to .config, or to change setting for programs without config files (like less).
Also let's say I start my terminal emulator. That runs my shell. And that shell needs to have my environment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90688271
/etc/environment, /etc/bash_profile or /etc/zsh/zshenv for global variables and ~/.zshenv or ~/.bash_profile for user variables

posts.name: Shadowfire
posts.com:
>>90688271
I put them in .bash_aliases along with shellopts, aliases, functions.... for portability. And distro-specific stuff in it's own section.
To launch firefox with GTK_USE+PORTAL=1 I copied the system firefox.desktop file to a ~ containing other .desktop files to have an appropriate path to it, then edited each "Exec" line to prefix the command with the variable. Now I has firefox file picker icons whether firefox is launched by menu, toolbar, or some other program that uses firefox to open a page.
>Right way, wrong way, my way.
#in .bashrc
# source the ~/.bash_aliases file if it exists.
if [ -f ~/.bash_aliases ]; then
. ~/.bash_aliases
fi
#

This looks like a binary build instead of something that's been compiled specifically for Arch. You're going to run into those sorts of issues when you use third-party binaries. posts.name: Anonymous

Syslinux just works if you don't have complex requirements.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90689974
The standards of copyright law and the standards of artists in terms of plagiarism are quite different.
If copyright law was the only concern AI artists could simply operate out of China since it basically doesn't exist over there.
Plagiarizing something even once is a scarlet letter in the art industry.
It's a bit like cheating in speedrunning. The real life consequences? Basically non-existent. But whenever anyone googles your name they get five hour-long videos about how you're a shameful cheating liar with links to ten-page long bibliographies in the pinned comment.

To give an example, there's a game I like called FE8_GIRLS. It's a Fire Emblem romhack.
The maker, a Japanese individual who goes by Chap, at one point used animations from an American Fire Emblem romhack.
Someone apparently found this out, tracked Chap down, and got him to remove them from the game. There's still an apology from him about it in the readme.
These are two games that between them have maybe 20,000 players globally between them and are in two entirely different languages, and it still got found out.
Rationally, nobody should care about something this minor, but it's an honor code. Artists look out for each other. If you steal from another artist, you break that trust. If enough people steal, the circle of trust is ruined for everyone.

Later in 2018, ProtonMail was hit with another DDoS attack. After the attack appeared to have ended, ProtonMail CTO, Dr. Bart Butler, mocked the attacker and then later goaded them via Twitter.[15] In response to the harassment, the attacker restarted the attack with increased strength resulting in ProtonMail being taken offline again. The attackers said 3 times they would stop the attack if ProtonMail CTO, Dr. Butler, apologized. Dr. Butler would not apologize for publicly mocking and goading the attacker, so the DDoS continued. ProtonMail tried to blame the DDoS attacks on Russia,[16] jumping onto the "Just blame Russia" bandwagon. Everyone who had the facts disagreed with ProtonMail's "blame Russia" approach, including their own contractor, Radware. As ProtonMail was trying to figure out where it was coming from, Krebsonsecurity came to the rescue and identified the attacker as an autistic teen living in the UK.[17] ProtonMail later credited him officially. ProtonMail was not taken offline by Russia after all, it turns out it was pretty easy to do.

In very small numbers, usually as "a thing". Like suddenly deciding to write a heartfelt letter to your wife or mother or someone as a birthday gift or something to show your lifelong appreciation.

Last year I had occasion to send a medical document back to my general practitioner, a very nice caring japanese lady. All I had to do slip the thing in an envelope and send it off, nothing else was required, but I thought, fuck it, I'll try and exercise a tiny bit of forgotten decency and included a little letter with all the boilerplate niceties thanking her for her ongoing care and so on. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90690544
Apply for many internships. Go to your school's career fair.

If you have trouble getting callbacks, try looking for work you can do for your school. IT stuff, undergraduate research, whatever, so you can put it on your resume.

If you have trouble passing interviews or online assessments, practice leetcode.

If you're asking generally how to improve yourself as a programmer and not how to get an internship - if you're interested in a particular subfield, learn a lot about that subfield, pick up books, read them, toy around with code, do relevant side projects, contribute to open source projects, etc.
If you don't have anything in particular you're interested in but want to improve, learn more about full-stack development.

>Better DAC/amp

>Physical buttons

>Some people can't use smartphone at work/use dumbphones

>Source (phone or PMP)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I am impressed by Final E500. I had a lot of lowered expectations from: hearsay about QC concerns, looking at graphs and seeing unit variance & channel imbalance, hearing a similar proposition as Chu in that you "Buy it for the tips, $5 goes towards IEM," etc. Pretty stunned at the sound. I can find very little fault other than the obvious nobasslmao preference. It still gives good detail and texture in the low end, just not at a quantity or slam-level that meets most tastes. Tonality from mids through upper treble is great. Natural and clear, but just stepped back in comparison to typical Moondrop/Salnotes Zero-esque presence. There is nothing I can remark on as inadequate or subpar in any realm of technicalities or mumbo jumbo, the driver sounds great, above average. I have no issues with channel imbalance in my pair. I can also hear why Final doubles down on marketing towards 3D/360 sound, it does excel at imaging and soundstage for the price and btfo'd my own preconceived notions. I find them comfortable. You can play with insert depth easily with the different included tips, I went balls deep and they sound excellent. I rec em if you want low-bass dark treble, cheap imaging and soundstage, and simple comfy bullet-style. Not rec'd for bassheads, treble "detail" chasers, or enhanced female vocal lovers. Hot take conclusion: I would buy these over Hexa and pocket the savings.

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Is Optimize-Offline worth it?
>Should I debloat?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Open up regedit
>Go to HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows
>Create the key Explorer if that doesn't exist
>Go inside Explorer and add the DWORD DisableSearchBoxSuggestions add set it to 1
Then you might as well also disable the dynamic search box too.
>Go to HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\SearchSettings
>Add the DWORD IsDynamicSearchBoxEnabled and leave it set to 0
>Restart your PC
Now you shouldn't have internet shit in Windows Search anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90682077
HWID activates a system forever by giving an identifier to MS, which basically just has their servers saying that "this configuration of hardware is authorized to use this edition of Windows fully activated." It's good if you ever need to re-install your system or something because as the HWID is connected to your hardware and the edition you installed, it'll re-activate itself when you get back in. Though if you do ever lose the HWID you can just re-run the activator and get another one.
KMS has activation that lasts 180 days and refreshes itself at the end of each period. KMS activators like KMS_VL_ALL create a local server in system32 that the activation looks for/uses to refresh itself. It's another fine way to activate your Windows, though like I've said IoT LTSC can only be activated with HWID. There's no non-privacy friendly shit involved, you're just another number in the vast amount of numbers that exist in their servers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90679328
>I think its closer to the size of physical manga than 10 inches is
Manga has several size
-B5 for magazines, 176mm × 250mm
-A5 for 4koma and other high detail/low frequency tankobon, 148mm × 210mm
-B6 for standard tankobon, 125mm × 176mm
-Shinshoban for series with high output, 105mm × 173mm
This corresponds with the 13", 10", 8" and 7" panels.
Since manga is supposed to be read with double pages you need twice that size, hence why 13" is the only read option.

>>90696548
I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're refering to as backlight, is in fact, a front light, or as I've recently taken to calling it, light from the front. Backlight is not an universal lighting solution unto itself, but rather another physical component of a fully functioning LCD system made useful by the LCD panel, polarization filter and vital system components comprising a full display as defined by IEEE.

Many e-reader users run a modified version of the front light system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of light which is widely used today is often called backlight, and many of its users are not aware that it is actually a front light, shining light on top of the screen.

There really are backlights, and these people are using them, but it is just a part liquid crystal displays. Backlight is the illumination solution on a LCD: the lightsource that illuminates the panel so they can be seen. The backlight is an essential part of an liquid crystal display, but useless on an e-reader; it can only function in the context of a complete liquid crystal display. e-ink is normally used in combination with a front light: the whole system is basically a light shining on top of the screen, or front light. All the so-called backlit e-readers are really frontlit!

>>90689088
I have a couple chink wands
>corded
It cost 11 eurobux and broke almost immediately. The motor would constantly run at a slow speed and whatever programs you chose would run kind of on top of that (saw at least one review with the same problem). I fixed it by replacing the mosfet from a different chink vibrator controller. On the inside there is a large board that is actually just a 5V power supply and a small board barely larger than the button area that does all the motor controls. It's a decently powerful vibrator that has like 30 programs but it's not a very good design, the soft surround on the head comes off quite easily.
>rechargeable
It cost 19 euro and is better quality. I thought it would be just a battery version of the white one but it's a different model entirely, the construction is much better. The vibrating power is the same, I'm guessing the actual vibrator motor inside the head is the same in all the chink ones. It's got less programs as well but it's still my favorite vibrator, pretty much just werks aside from the head cushion also occasionally coming off. I'll probably fashion some kind of solution from two-sided tape one of these days.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90691902
>Has anyone bought phone parts from china?
Screens are hit or miss. Sometimes they'll be perfectly fine, other times they have colour issues or flat out die within weeks. Reviews on Ali and forums are your best bet to make sure you don't buy trash. Alternatively you could hit up one of those local phone repair stores.

Internal components are fine as long as your phone doesn't use shitty measures like unique hardware ID's on each component to prevent unauthorized repairs. These components will often be legit, typically salvaged from either broken or stolen phones that got send to China for disassembly and resale. It's an entire industry at this point as manufacturers still refuse to sell parts to consumers or "unauthorised" repair shops.

Batteries are a minefield. Knockoffs and third party brands with poor quality control and fake capacities are everywhere. Modern phones put a lot of stress on batteries with techniques such as fast charging and I can't trust them to not burn my house down. Honestly, just pay the premium for an official battery or at least stick with home brands from respected local (web)stores.

>>90695791
>It doesn't matter how many times they repeat "original" and "official" on their product page.
While I agree, it does make it an instant win when filing a dispute and showing what you received was not an original/official part. Pretty useful when dealing with old or obscure devices whose batteries that can't be sourced locally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
they're mostly a meme
your vpn doesn't *want* to collect logs (since doing so increases their liability, and would be a nuclear self-destruct button on their entire business if they were ever exposed)
that doesn't mean that they're completely safe; feds DO issue gag orders, an order along the lines of "we think *user* is a pedophile, log their traffic and don't disclose this order" would basically force the vpn to comply, jurisdiction dependent. this kind of order is obscenely unlikely if you're just infringing on copyright and not, you know, sharing pizza
for normies who want to change their geoip for netflix or whatever, sure they're useful. they are useful for torrenting, but i'd really recommend getting a seedbox instead (not a whole lot more expensive, can also be used as a private vpn that doesn't send you to captcha hell)
if you're using windows or macos, nothing you do on your computer is private whatsoever, vpn or not.

>>90668161
RAID allows you to withstand drive failure WITHOUT needing to lose any data and without ever needing to go offline. this is true only of RAID1, 5, 6 and cominations such as 50 and 10
without RAID, if you have a drive fail, you need to replace the missing data. with RAID, you don't need to replace the missing data, because it's still there live on the system (depending on the RAID level)
it's like having two power supplies - if one fails, you don't just shut off and lose power, you keep going on the second power supply and can replace the faulty one with zero doesntime. that's what redundant means, and thats why RAID and backups are totally different things and should never be used interchangeably.
you can also use things like RAD0 if you just have a bunch of disks and only want to have one "drive" in the system, perhaps for organisation purposes or to simply network shares - RAID0 also has the benefit of speeding up read/write performance.

>>90668406
>that's what backups are for
no, without RAID if you suffer drive failure you lose all data on that drive and must replace it with the backup. with RAID, if you siffer drive failure you only have to replace the drive - the data is still available the entire time.

a backup restoration involves having a second copy of the data that must be kept up to date in order to be restored. with RAID, ALL data is available across the entire array such that if any drive fails, ALL data is still present without need for human intervention. there is no need to "restore" data because no data was ever lost - only the parity data, which just needs to be rebuilt and can be done while the original data is still accessed.
>true but i dont care about that
then you don't need to care about RAID. but it is very different from having a backup and serves an entirely different function.
"i don't care about xyz feature" doesn't mean that xys is not a feature or that it doesn't serve a unique function.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90668161
>that's what backups for are
Backups aren't updated online and continuously, only periodically. This means that if you have to resort to a backup, you've lost the data since you've last updated it. On top of that there's also the fact that the RAID remains usable even with a drive dead, which I find very nice because if a drive in my server dies it may take me a few days to replace it and a few days without access to my data would be a significant inconvenience to me. Fixing it may potentially require ordering a new drive, plus I don't always have the time to drop everything and take the server out to work on it, not to mention that restoring from backup in and of itself can be a very long operation if a large drive dies.

Also yes, performance is better as well with RAID than a single HDD.

>-What precautions should I take to not be a complete security retard?

Check out Wolfgang's Channel on youtube for some good beginner-friendly advice, but also just searching around fo "homelab" or "home server" or "diy NAS" is a good place to start

>>90669756
if example.com points to your network's public IP, and your router forwards port 80 to your servers IP, then you just add to apache's config that "jellyfin/example/com" goes to "jellyfin-server-IP-address:port number"
users only need to go to "jellyfin.example.com" and it will forward them to the server, no need to enter a port number - by default "example.com" will come in on port 80, which you have forwarded to your apache server. apache sees that the incomming request is from "jellyfin.example.com" and forwards it to the right address:port

bear in mind this needs you to register not only example.com, but the subdomain jellyfin.example.com
subdomains are free if you already own the domain, but you will still need to set it up and have it point to your IP address

Raid (to me It's Raid Z1,2,3 cause that's what I use) is a lifesaver. Drive failure, power off, replace the dead drive, power on. Let the pool resliver. You go on with life. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90668161
RAID is for ensuring uptime and avoiding the need to actually use your backups. Say you're a data hoarder like me and you have roughly 50 TB of storage occupied. Without raid, an HDD fails and your system is down. You need to restore from backup. Depending on the backup medium (a backup this large will probably be on the cloud), you'll be down for days. Whereas with the proper RAID setup, you can remove the failed HDD, place a new one, rebuild the array (should be at most a couple of hours), and keep on chugging. You should have backups, but you don't want to have to use them, ideally.

this is only updated once every xyz time units, and the larger the dataset the longer a backup takes. RAID is ALWAYS in sync, there is no potential to lose data so long as you only have N number of drive failures where N is the number of redundant drives your RAID level allows. you can even set online hot spares so that the array will automatically rebuild onto a new drive when one fails, meaning you don't even need to deal with a degraded array for longer than just the rebuild time.

RAID is about ZERO DOWNTIME WHATSOEVER, it's got nothing to do with dataloss. if you don't need ZERO DOWNTIME WHATSOEVER then stop thinking about RAID because it has ZERO RELEVANCE to you whatsoever. but for people that do need it, it's a great solution. and people do need it, in fact most enterprise servers have redundnat EVERYTHING, not just drives, so you could lose an drive, power supply, CPU, server, rack, internet coonection or even power to the building and a redunant something would kick in. >>90671870
drives die regardless of how much or how little you use them. every drive fails at a different rate, but every HDD WILL fail at some point or other. if you are replacing drives before they fail, then you're never going to experience a drive failure. I've had drives with no data on them die after being plugged in for two years doing nothing, and I've had drives running as buffer-recording devices for security cameras live for 8+ years without ever being powered off or stopping writing.

using a backup drive while resotring a backup is a HORRIBLE idea because it drastically increases the chance of your ONLY REMAINING BACKUP failing. 2 is 1, 1 is none.

once again, RAID and backups are entirely different things.

>Do I need ECC RAM?
no. it's nice to have, but not necesary. that being said, it's also not very expensive to get, however if you're using existing hardware it almost certainly doesn't support it, otherwise you'd already know that it does
>Do I need a Server OS?
strictly speaking, no. it's avised, depending on what you wanna do. I think minecraft servers run just fine under windows, for example, however the OS will eat into a fraction of your system resources, and non-server OSes like windows tend to do things you might not like, for example restarting to install updates in the middle of a game
you should look into what game servers you want to run, and see if they are supported on any of the common server OS's like windows server (which is a paid OS and can't really be used unlicensed like regular windows can), ubuntu/debian, or even things like proxmox (debian but with a suite of software for virtualising applications, called "containers")
>I’ve heard CPU and RAM are the most important components for this.
get yourself a ryzen whatever with a buncha cores and you're sorted. I personally would reccomend 32GB ram minimum but that's preference, you probably won't need that much. again, you already have existing hardware so I'd run with that first and see what is holding you back after a month or two
>Is it possible to run multiple instances?
yes, in the same way it's possible to run multiple games on your computer at once. they just all take up x% of your system resources. for gameservers it's usually quite low compared to the game itself, but it depends on the game and how many users etc.

I'm pretty sure minecraft even has like, comunity made server images you can just deploy via docker or something and have a fully operational server in seconds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90676088
>-Does setting up a home-server mean the computer will be drawing full power at all times?
no, the max rated TDP of your parts is just that - the MAX rated TDP. a 400w GPU will only pull 400W at peak load, it could very well idle at 5w (i doubt it but you get the idea)
obviously more power-hunry devices will use more power, but it's not going to be sitting at 100% usage at all times. you could just buy one of those power plug watt meters and check it out though.
My server rack at home included three 750w computers, two 75w switches and a 80w router, and under average conditions the entire rack pulls only like 200w. under load from the one server with a GPU and high-spec CPU in it, that jumps up to around 500w, but still well under the theoretical total of 2.4Kw (or more like 1.4Kw if you go by the parts and not by the PSUs)
point is, no, the parts wont draw full load at all times.
>Hybrid EFI technology with DualBIOS for 3TB HDD support
I'm not sure, but I've never really heard of a motherboard limiting the size of your drive. I'm pretty sure your average SATA controller from a decade ago could support like 10TB or above
I'd check around the manuals and specsheets rather than the sales pages, though

I can't imaging you needing more than 3TB on a single drive for a game server, anyway. Pretty sure most real production gameservers only have like 1TB flash storage anyway, since updates are usually done via a delta and the update files are storaged elsewhere

>throw rsync in a cronjob and you are done
cron is literally scheduled, you lose data between scheduled runs. I don't think you understand what "online" means here, it means that the process itself to write a file to a RAID actually writes to all disks at once, there is NO period of time in which the file is only stored on a single drive.

>>90687120
A couple of reasons:
>linux is free, windows is not (it can be used for free, while being limited in some capacity (on server a LOT more than on desktop))
>less overhead from the operating system, if your setup is low on resources
>theres a lot more "server-y" stuff built for linux than there is for windows, many server applications are systemd daemons or intended to be run as systemd daemons, and don't really have a windows counterpart
>being headless makes remoting into the server much easier, protocols like RDP and VNC are a lot more complex to setup, use and secure than ssh is
>speaking of ssh, window's terminal is almost entirely useless - even powershell doesn't do a whole lot
>you can also put a GUI on a linux server, but the GUI's on most linux distros make things more difficult instead of less
>doesn't need to be modified in order to actually run as a server
>won't ever randomly turn off to install updates, or randomly delete your files because it thinks they are a virus

theres some valid reasons to use windows as a server, and that's why they made windows server, but the desktop sides of windows really aren't made to be run as a server and therefore they require a hell of a lot more, and more complicated, configuration to run as a server. it's actually MORE difficult to use windows 10 pro as a fileserver than it is to use debian or arch linux, since you need to fuck around with the registry to disable automatic updates, and window's NTFS permissions can create massive headaches even on windows-only networks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90687667
like for example, heres the basic steps for setting up a windows 10 pro fileserver vs an ubuntu one
windows 10 pro:
>install the OS and disable all the cortana and shit during setup
>disable updates from the metro settings app
>delete/modify three or four registry keys to *actually* disable automatic updates (aka the part that shuts down your machine after 3 days of not updating)
>change network adaptor properties from control panel (not metro settings) to set a static IP
>change network and sharing centre settings to allow file and folder sharing and network discovery
>create a folder to share and make sure it has the correct permissions
>share it to either "everyone" or "authenticated users"
>make sure the user account of the server is not the same name as any other user accounts on your network
>ensure that all accounts on your network have a password, or disable password protected sharing
>on the client, in command prompt type "net use x: //192.168.0.69/shared_folder"

on ubuntu
>sudo useradd smbuser
>sudo mkdir /mnt/share
>sudo chown smbuser:smbuser /mnt/share
>sudo apt install smbd
>sudo nano /etc/samba/smb.conf
add 
[share]
    comment = samba file share
    path = /mnt/share
    read-only = no
    browsabe = yes
    writeable = yes
    force user = smbuser

>on the client windows machine, open command prompt and type "net use x: //192.168.0.69/share"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90691378
You're typical HDD won't be faster than around 120MB/s, and even RAIDZ1 as you've seen doesn't go much higher than 800MB/s on spinning disk, so when you consider than 10Gbe is 1250MB/s, you start to get diminishing returns pretty quick. If you're running SSDs then 25g and 40g make more sense, but for HDDs, 10Gbe is as fast as you could ever possibly need anyway

The only 40g I have ever really used is in uplinks between switches, so that you could potentially have either 4 10g connections at full speed, or 40 gigabit connections at full speed between two switches, but the use cases for this are pretty rare in the home environment. Even my 10g switch at home only uplinks to the router at 10g, not that it matters much since my internet is less than gigabit anyway

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90695588
>And why should I run RAID6 instead of RAID10?
less wasted space at the sacrifice of some speed. depends on what's more important - i'd argue they have the same level of redundancy (two drive failures, although in 6 it can be any two drives, in 10 they must be from different mirrors)

i run raid6 because i only have 10 drive bays, so i'm only losing 20TB to parity as opposed to 50TB in raid10. but raid 5 and 6 are a lot slower, so keep that in mind.

80W is definitely doable, yes. It will depend on how many HDDs you have spinning, but they only use a few W each.
>I might do that then. Is there any use case for the GPU?
Well those CPUs don't have an iGPU as far as I remember. You'll probably want SOME form of video output available, just in case something ever goes wrong and the system is no longer accessible by network. A graphics card can also be used for HW accelerated transcoding for media servers, or you can do things like pass one through to a VM. For instance I have a Windows VM with a card passed through, I sometimes use it when I don't need the full performance of my main desktop, or when I want to stream a game to some other place in my house.

>>90673136
Been a while since I watched it but he is laying out a thought experiment. You can't move a n high tower, but you can decompose it into a series of moves using a n-1 high tower. Technically, if n=4 then n-1 is still too tall, but leaving that aside you can forge ahead and decompose the moves you can't make using a n-1-1 tower. If you keep doing this you will decompose the problem into a series of allowable moves. Hope that helps.

not exactly what you asked but you can figure it out:
(define my-alist
  '((a . 420)
    (b . 69)
    (c . 1337)
    (d . 1010)))

(define print-entry
  (lambda (alist k)
    (let ((entry (assq k alist)))
      (display "key: ")
      (display (car entry))
      (display ", value: ")
      (display (cdr entry)))))

(print-entry my-alist 'a)


you need to use assoc/assv/assq. if your keys are symbols, assq is the fastest

>>90688595
Thanks. I can see winner-mode being useful in certain contexts, but it's limited to moving through a linear timeline of window configuration changes. If I wanted to jump back 5 configurations ago, I'd have to traverse through the changes in between which is suboptimal.

I want to be able to give names to window configurations and jump straight to them, O(1) style. O(n) for large values of n is no fun. Here is my solution for that problem.

(defvar w/configs (make-hash-table :test #'equal)
  "This is a hash-table where window configurations used by w/save and w/load are stored.")

(defun w/save (key)
  "Save the current window configuration to w/configs."
  (interactive "sName for window configuration: ")
  (puthash key
           (window-state-get (frame-root-window) t)
           w/configs))

(defun w/load (key)
  "Load a named window configuration from w/configs."
  (interactive
   (let* ((completion-ignore-case t)
          (completions '())
          (nothing (maphash (lambda (k v) (push k completions)) w/configs)))
     (list (completing-read "Choose: " completions nil t))))
  (window-state-put (gethash key w/configs)))


- When I'm have a window configuration I want to jump back to later, I use M-x w/save and give the config a name.
- When I want to go back, I use M-x w/load and I'm given a list of past window configs.
- If I have configs I use often, I can preload them into the w/configs hash-table.

I wrote my system to overcome one limitation of window-configuration-to-register. The window-configuration data structure that it uses and stores in registers is "opaque" in the sense that you can't serialize it as a plain elisp data structure. It's a thin wrapper for some C structs. That's a problem, because I can't save a window configuration in a way that can survive an emacs restart.

I would have happily used window-configuration-to-register if the window-configuration data it put in registers were serializable, but it wasn't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90688822
when I wrote the window parts of my config, I came to the conclusion there were only four configurations I actually use:
- single window
- two vertically split windows
- three windows, with one on the left half and two, horizontally split, on the right half
- four windows in a diamond shape
and I mapped these to C-c w [1-4] and never worried again. I also have a function to rotate the buffers, which I use a lot in the three-window setup:

(defun samedi/rotate-list (n lst)
  "Returns a list consisting of the elements of LST, shifted N places.
Positive N shifts to the right, Negative N shifs to the left."
  (let ((n (mod n (length lst))))
    (append (last lst n) (butlast lst n))))

(defun samedi/rotate-buffers (&optional reverse)
  "Rotates the currently open buffers across the windows of the current frame."
  (let ((rotated-buffer-list (samedi/rotate-list (if reverse -1 1) (mapcar #'window-buffer (window-list)))))
    (mapc (lambda (x)
            (let ((window-index (seq-position (window-list) x)))
              (set-window-buffer x (nth window-index rotated-buffer-list))))
          (window-list))))

When you post the submission make sure that the song is clearly a submission for the album, otherwise it might get skipped.
Songs that contain anything against YouTube's policies won't be uploaded on YT (but will still be added to the album)

https://rentry.org/dmpalbums

If your ultimate goal is to go modular, I'd start the old Reason. I don't remember the exact version but there's one particular favorite before it went to shit.
For controlling notes something like the MAudio keystation second hand should be very cheap and a good starter. Later, when you figure out some shit, you can get other stuff for faders and knobs. I'm assuming you're making music on a desktop PC.
If you're on a laptop, maybe something like the keystep pro, although it's expensive, it's a pretty good pack. If you want full-sized keys, the keylab essential... but I'd only recommend full sized keys if you're into playing solos and full chords or improvising over tracks. For stuff like synthwave, sequencers and arpeggiators are the way to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90692579
Yeah, when you begin to learn music production in a computer it's mostly pointing and clicking. Notes are the most troublesome part to write, everything else you can automate or program. You can use your MIDI keyboard for drums too, so a drumpad is not essential at first. The less things you have to deal with at the beginning, the faster you're gonna learn. You're gonna have to trust me on this one. DAWs and virtual synths are an endless rabbit hole, and it's better to explore them first -a lot- and then see what hardware you need for your specific goals instead of the other way around. If you reach a point where you simply can't live without an extra fader or knob, you can customize your controllers with exactly what you need for a cheap buck or maybe during your learning curve save money to get that fancy controller of your dreams. You'll probably change your mind a couple of times while you learn, maybe you decide that the computer is not enough and go for a hybrid or full DAW-less setup. Go very slow on the spending because if you don't have a clear goal and buy the wrong thing, it can get pretty frustrating. It's also overwhelming to have a lot of stuff that you don't use. A good performer's live set has no more than 3 or 4 pieces of gear.

Long-time P2P developer and infosec professional here (have worked on Freenet, Tor, I2P and others), have spoken with LE and spooks and many others about challenges relating to anon networks and CSAM.

I have never heard of these Secjuice bozos.

The Fediverse has a LOT less trouble than -chans - it's federated, not decentralised. If it exists, it's siloed in its own walled garden. Maybe they're referring to pixiv's instance (which indeed, is siloed in its own walled garden due to Japan's differing laws at the time, although I think Japan changed its law? idk, not a fan, so I don't really care). The reason -chans have a problem is the ease of posting without accounts, plus many chans that aren't 4chan have fairly inactive mods.

However it is true that anonymous platforms do tend to have a problem with pedos wanting to abuse the platform with CSAM - that is why you shouldn't use Freenet anymore - and decentralised ones do tend to not have very good systems for dealing with platform abuse such as spam or, well, pedos wanting to abuse the platform - that is why you shouldn't use eMule anymore.

That said, by far and away most pedos use Kik, Wickr, or fucking Facebook with their real names, and anonymous networks make LE infiltration easier, not harder (see the very large LE operation on the old Tor site 'Playpen' for an example). The threat is massively overstated, often deliberately so.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I did it. I caved in and finally bought my first Graf von Faber-Castell fountain pen. This is now my most expensive fountain pen, at roughly 237 USD (after conversion). Despite the colour of the nib in the pic, it is an 18K gold nib but is coated with rhodium. I like the writing experience; it's very smooth but not overly smooth, as in it does have just the smallest touch of resistance/feedback/scratchy or whatever you wanna call it.

Reviews online have said that the metal parts of this pen are "fingerprint magents" but honestly in my experience it's nowhere near as bad. It's a lot of fingerprint resistant than the reviews make it out to be. What I find most surprising about this pen, however, is the fact that the grip section is somehow non-slippery, despite being all-metal. I rarely find myself having to re-adjust my fingers when gripping the grip section, even though my hands are often lotioned. Length of the pen without the cap is 126/127 mm, which is comfortable enough for me. Though I do think if it were just a teensy bit longer (like 130 mm), it would've been perfect.

The only negative thing I can say about the pen is that you have to make sure the nib unit is properly saturated after filling, which can be done by expelling a drop of ink back into the bottle after refilling. First time I used by directly filling the converter, it had the rare and occasional problem of hard starting/skipping a bit at the start of a letter. After I saturated the nib unit, that problem disappeared. Regardless, it's got a 1 year warranty so I can simply exchange if I ever run into issues.

So yeah, anons, talk about fountain pens. What'er you using right now? Any recent purchases?
posts.filename: Graf von Faber-Castell Guilloche Viper Green

>>90679931
I'm gonna assume that's 500-800 mA then. So 6-10 hours of that on the 5000mAh battery. Not bad at all, but that does mean that your 1%/10mins figure isn't true. Still better than most phones though. It's basically like a smart car with a few jerrycans of fuel in the boot. Big range because you have no way of burning it fast.

Ideally manufacturers would try to get more out of the fast chips, but I guess that wouldn't sell. My own fucking about with undervolting, underclocking and slight alterations to the powerhints.json file has given me some decent gains in battery without affecting performance.
Basically where stock lineageos would pull 240mA or so doing simple things like reading shit on 4chan, my settings have it chill around 200 and below. Probably 20% savings overall? Even tiktok went from 8-9%/h to like 6-7% if I had to guess. Some of the default durations for boosting for example are pretty ridiculous. Like 5 seconds of all core boosted minimum clocks on app launch, or the boost when you use the touchscreen.

But of course I spend way too much time on this lmao.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90665701
Requirements for ML:
- Quick iteration iteration time (lots of parameters to check for any arch choice)
- Ease of modifying the overall arch/workflow
- Accelerated single-block compute (all compute happens at once, repeatedly, with no need to move back to python runtime for a long long time)
- Good tool facilities (tensor manipulation, text and stats/prob toolkits, etc.)

Things nobody gives a shit about:
- Fast non-library speed (virtually no time is spent in the python runtime)
- Verbosity
- Low level memes (makes modifications harder, too verbose, greatly reduces turnaround time, error risk requires far more time and effort to work out, no room for mistakes due to long runtimes)

They do it by building tools. Every third-party “tool” is actually a weakness: it’s doing something that either didn’t need to have been done at all, or could have been done better in the first place. however, it creates a community. There’s a way for people to contribute. It’s like a game that leaves little bonuses lying around for people to pocket. If even a novice can make a small contribution, so much better. They feel good about themselves, and now they’ve made a commitment to that ecosystem. The switching costs suddenly became significantly higher. In the realm of programming languages, this is especially true. And in fact, to be “successful” in terms of size, perhaps every language should start out somewhat flawed.. it should have bad scope rules, weird modules, funky overloading, floating points as the only numbers, and so on. To a rational observer, this might seem an awful idea. but programmers, as a species, have gotten acculturated to salt mines as a natural habitat. They will think nothing of it. Of course, you need something to draw them in: “one weird trick” that lets them do entirely unnecessary and perhaps wholly unwise things that let them demonstrate virtuosity. The latter draws them in, and the former seals the commitment. One could view C++ templates as a form of the latter.

Customers regard more highly an organization that has recovered well from failure than one that had not yet failed. Good designs are like the latter: they do not fail, and therefore cannot pleasantly surprise you. Inferior designs fail, but when the community comes to your rescue, you are left happier than you were before.

When you add a feature you are making a commitment to it. The features you add increase scope. The point of a language is to build a tool to solve problems. MLfags are mostly cstards, not mathinbreds, so that wasn't very attractive (the ones with math degrees are those who graduated before CS degrees existed for the most part. On the other hand there is a decent chunk of mlfags with a stat phys background).
The reason python was the winner is also related: the new crop of people interested in ML were uniquely in the CS camp, and mostly knew python (or if not could pick it up easily). Lua, on the other hand, is a much rarer language in colleges.
Then the rest is the same momentum dynamics that C and unix enjoyed, for example. Because people knew python, tools were made in python, thus people learned python... for ML.
But it's true, a major defect of python for ML is that the C interop overhead is massive. This isn't a huge problem since back-and-forth are minimal in most ML applications, but lua doesn't have this problem, and the corollary is that it makes C libraries with bindings in lua far more usable (think numpy-for-lua). It also makes writing small acceleration code in C far easier (in python, you have to resort to numba (very limited), cython (python-flavored C, very complicated to build in non-trivial cases, let alone distribute, rarely actually that fast), python.h's horrid interface, or ctypes and its immense overhead, i.e. no good options at all).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>PhD requirement to even enter the field
As a PhD student, let me let you in on a little secret... most CS PhDs can't fucking program to save their life. Time spent studying theory and advanced mathematics is time not spent learning how to properly design and maintain software, nor is it time spent using any remotely complicated languages. Python is common in AI, data science, and anything in between precisely because it is simple. Academics love Python because it allows them to focus on the task they're trying to accomplish, without regards to the implementation details.

What matters isn't that you write a good program. You don't have users. You have yourself. Your program will be run however many times it takes to get results for a paper, and then it is unlikely to be run again. Unless, of course, one intends to write a follow up paper. Speed is relevant only insofar as machine learning is very computationally expensive... so all of the code for training these things is written in C or C++, with bindings to use the library within Python.

I personally like programming. About a year or so ago, I worked on some tools for a project I was doing with some power systems folks. One of them could have been used in pretty much any language with a graph library, so I used Rust. Not because it needed to be fast, but because I wanted to write something in Rust. I'm in a minority in academia though. For most people, writing software is a means to an end and nothing more. If it can be done in Python, it will.

Lisp isn't hard to learn because of the core syntax. It's hard to learn because of all the other idiosyncratic details of any specific Lisp that you have to learn before you can do simple things. Common Lisp being a lisp-2, for example. Clojure has some wierd javalike scaffolding, understanding how entrypoints work can be a little painful for a new programmer. Racket is full of autustic academic shit that you hit the moment you try to do something you think would be simple like load some data from json or yaml.

None of those issues have anything to do with syntax. You can even use Hy, which is basically python with lisp syntax, to get a feel for how little the parens really matter.

>>90665701
>why the fuck does ML use python
Because it's easy. Fantastic for training, experimenting and also prototyping. If I need to show board something, I'm going to do it all in jupyter notebook and run through the shit, or email them a PDF of the notebook. Python should however NOT be used for deployment.
To use myself as an example, I've spent over two decades programming. I transitioned into ML about 8 years ago. I do my data preprocessing and training in python. I do all my experiments and testing in python. I deploy all my shit in C++ and CUDA, whatever python I use for deployment is minimal and doesn't require dependencies past the version of python.
I can understand how someone that didn't have a programming background would just stick to python for deployment, but honestly, they shouldn't be deploying. The company should hire someone else to do that, or they should hire competent ML people that are also competent programmers.
It's a really easy to use language but fucking wasteful, and if you're working at scale, it just burns through resources.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90687539
Map editor efficiency literally doesn't matter in 2D. In fact even a nearly naive implementation of a 2D game engine will give you good enough perf so long as the backend stack is solid (e.g. don't expect great perf if you're doing software rendering by putting pixels in a bitmap and then converting that to png and then displaying that).
Also, >>90687578 is a great strategy. Not only does it ensure your result will look as you want it to in-engine, effects and all, it also helps stress-test your engine, makes it possible to expose the map editor to modders if you ever want to do that, and enable a more dynamic development experience where you could be able to enable limited playtesting just as you edit the map.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90688150
>>90688264
You can and should go even further than that: each component of your game should be a different dynamic library (i.e. one for the AI module, one for the graphics, one for sounds... you can even go as far as one per entity). The reason is that this allows you to recompile only that component while the rest of the game is still running (i.e. this is how hot-reloading works in most cases; the alternative is monkey patching, which is usually trickier).
When you're ready for a release, you can just compile everything statically to benefit from lto, or just put it all in one ball to have full compile-time optimizations.

>>90656173
>I had a Keychron K2 awhile back. Battery was fine the first few months, but eventually died.
This is exactly what I want to avoid and why I insist on still using my rechargeable AA batteries. It's the reason I won't get the latest Xbox controllers and still use a Xbox Series controller.
Lithium ion batteries can last a decently long time if they are perfectly taken care of, but you have to know to discharge it to 50% when you aren't going to use it for awhile and not ever leave it fully charged for extended periods of time, and possibly even undercharge it a little bit in general if the battery management system doesn't already do that. They are very finicky and it doesn't take much to mess them up. The more devices I own with lithium-ion batteries, the more of a chore it becomes to take care of all those batteries. It's even more of a pain if they are all non-removable, because then I can't even share batteries between my devices, meaning more total batteries in my house.
It's starting to look like I'm going to have to build my own mechanical keyboard, which will probably mean paying someone to 3D print some shitty quality case with AA battery compartment. Luckily I hover type and so the keycaps will be the only part I touch while it's in use. I just hope I don't lose interest in the project before I figure out everything I need to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90672221
You have no idea what you're talking about. How fast they drain depends on capacity of the battery and obviously on the current pulled from it, not on voltage. Any device designed for AA batteries should have a dropout voltage (i.e. when it turns off due to the batteries being dead) of about 0.9V per cell, since if the battery voltage has dropped that low then most of the energy stored in the cell has been extracted. This is an entirely appropriate voltage level for both alkaline AAs (non-rechargeable, 1.5V nominal) and also for NiMH (rechargeable, 1.2V nominal) because they have different discharge curves, as in the 1.5V alkalines start at higher voltage but have a steeper drop while NiMH start at lower voltage but don't drop quite as fast. Ultimately, like I said, any device capable of extracting most of the energy from a 1.5V cell will also extract most of the energy from a 1.2V NiMH.

I suppose it's possible you used them on some super retarded device that's literally built wrong and wastes battery capacity by having its dropout set far too high, but that is going to die early on all types of batteries, though for NiMH it would be even worse. Personally I've used them on everything from toys to remotes and I've never seen it happen.

>>90672156
Something else must have happened. Li-ion is fairly fragile but it's not that fragile. You are correct that keeping batteries at max charge is not good for their long-term health but they don't die immediately. Think of all the laptops and shit which spend most of their time plugged in, unless you pull the short straw it takes years for significant degradation to set in. If your outright died then something else must've happened, probably the crappy electronics built into the things died or some such.

New to mechanical keyboards and looking at buying a Keychron Q1 or a GMMK Pro.
They both seem pretty similar. So I guess I'm wondering if anyone has any preference between them, and why?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90682478

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90682566
Q1 is a better out-of-the-box product and has a much more impactful gasket method, GMMK Pro has an extra key and is better for people who like to tinker with keyboards on both their hardware and their software.

List of changes I've made to my GMMK Pro:
>D65 gaskets from KBDfans
>FR4 plate from AVXWorks (borderline mandatory, FR4 plate feels amazing on GMMK Pro)
>different screws, because the screws used in the GMMK Pro are cheap
>removal of all case foam and plate foam
>VIA firmware install
>CMMK clip-in stabilizers from FL Esports
List of changes I've made to my Keychron Q5 in comparison:
>FR4 plate from Keychron

As mentioned the gasket mount on the GMMK Pro is nothing mindblowing (I don't find gasket mounts in general to be particularly impressive but GMMK Pro's isn't impressive no matter what you do), and the keyboard is a bit of an acoustic deadzone where all switches sound pretty much the same in its chassis unless you use an FR4 plate. The GOAT stabilizers are crap and massively overlubed out of the box, and I have no idea what their stabilizer v2s are like, which you'll probably get if your board was made more recently. Once tuned up, it's easily within the same quality bracket as the Keychron Q boards, but it takes work on your part to get there.

There's also the chance that you're satisfied with the Pro out of the box, and that's perfectly fine. I personally prefer the GMMK Pro to any other metal 75% I've tried, but this is after all the listed tweaks.

Disassembly for GMMK Pro is persnickety:
>Use the right size screwdriver head, neither too big nor too small, and be gentle with it to avoid stripping. It is a PH1 screwdriver head, or 3.0mm
>Make sure the RGB diffusers on the sides are put in properly! If they're put in upside down or even the wrong way across, the keyboard's knob will grind against the case
>The QMK flashing button is in a very stupid spot. You'll need to take the board apart a bit to reach it

React functional components accept a props object. It's popular to immediately destructure this object instead of referring to 
props.foo
. When combined with TypeScript typings, a typical component looks like this:
function Todo({ message, isDone }: { message: string; isDone: boolean }) {
  return null;
}


But that shit is retarded. I have to type the name of each prop twice, and it looks strange and ugly. I'd much rather pass each prop as its own parameter:
function Todo(message: string, isDone: boolean) {
  return null;
}


Why isn't this possible?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90687449
Because JSX looks like this:

<Todo message="hello" isDone={false} />


is transpiled as:

// h(component, props, children)
h(Todo, { message: "hello", isDone: false}, null);


// Which will call your component like:
Todo({ message: "hello", isDone: false });



Because objects keys aren't positional, you just cannot call it like that because JSX transforms the props you provide to your component as an object. If JSX transforms looked like

const message = "hello";
const isDone = false;
<Todo params={[message, isDone]} />

// which transformed in to:
h(Todo, ["hello", false], null);


// which calls todo like:
Todo(...params);


it would work, but there's really no benefit and only downsides with this approach.

However, you can opt out of React JSX perf optimisations by just calling the function, like:

function TodoList() {
  return (
  <div>
    {Todo("hello", false)}
  </div>
  );
}


But that would re-render the whole component every time the parent component re-renders, hooks wouldn't work either.

I personally prefer function keywords for components and any functions inside the components as "const", for code readability.

It's easier to type "export default function ..." than to have two lines that do the same thing with "const"

Functions also allow you to use generics, e.g. if you have a function component that iterates a array you'd want to use generics in your props.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90687198
Well, degrees are not necessarily seen as a hard requirement to be able to do the job. Even the most traditional of tech recruiters are well aware that good programmers can be self-taught.
The problem is that entry-level is an employer's market. There are more applicants than positions and recruiters can afford to be aggressively picky. Filtering out applicants without CS degrees is a quick way to reduce the number of resumes on their desk.
(The situation changes considerably once you have a year's experience or so, but that doesn't help you right now.)

Non-standard entry routes do exist. I started out on various freelancing platforms (the ones usually used by people in developing countries, with clients expecting to pay peanuts). It's easy to stand out on those places just by being a native English speaker, but you don't want to stay there for long. I managed to convince one of clients to work with me outside the platform and progressed from there.
However I've been studying an online CS degree alongside this work, to fill gaps and as insurance for the future. And I was fortunate to be in a position where I could devote a lot of time and energy to this instead of needing to hold down a full-time non-tech job.

tldr: I would encourage you to work towards a formal CS education. It's by far the safest bet. But keep looking for opportunities along the way- you might well be able to get hired before you actually get that degree.

posts.com:
>>90688597
>I guess I could use a preprocessor or babel transform or something to get the syntax I want,

Trust me: you don't. Chances are you may want to switch from Babel to SWC or something and it won't work at all. You could do it for the learning experience to learn a bit about AST's but relying on nonstandard transforms is the bane of large codebases.

You're also opting out of named params, a feature in many languages but the closest in JS is through an object as the first param, so it becomes more difficult to figure out what value should be in what position, because even though the params may be the same type you may be placing them in the incorrect positions.

Take this for example:

function Profile(name: string, age: number, shortBio: string, longBio: string) {
  return <div></div>
}

Profile("Jack", 18, "<long bio">, "<short bio>");


This would technically be correct in typing, but you've now misplaced two of the params. This would never happen unless you intentionally messed up on the object key name as well.

interface ProfileProps {
  name: string;
  age: number;
  shortBio: string;
  longBio: string;
}

function Profile(props: ProfileProps) {
  return <div></div>
}

Profile({ name: "Jack", age: 18, longBio: "<long bio>", shortBio: "<short bio>" });

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90679647
Before you go ahead, there are some differences besides impedance: 32Ω has shorter cable and pleather pads (less comfy, flake, muddier bass and less treble), 80Ω has longer cable and velour pads, 250Ω has coiled cable and velour pads.
If you plan on running them off some motherboard, higher impedance would actually be better since motherboards have usually very high output impedance. If it weren't for the coiled cable I'd actually recommend the 250Ω variant in that case.

Decent DACs or AMPs have digital resister ladder volume controls.

There are literally 8 or more relays and associated resistors. Each volume step has a certain pattern of relays that engage. So you are essentially changing the output resistance with enough precision to control the volume well.

What you really mean is Software Digital Volume. But that has gotten a lot better.

That's a trivial example from the getchar ref page.
https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/io/getchar
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

int main(void)
{ 
    int ch;
    while ((ch=getchar()) != EOF)   /* read/print "abcde" from stdin */
          printf("%c", ch);

    /* Test reason for reaching EOF. */
    if (feof(stdin))          /* if failure caused by end-of-file condition */
       puts("End of file reached");
    else if (ferror(stdin))   /* if failure caused by some other error      */
         {
            perror("getchar()");
            fprintf(stderr,"getchar() failed in file%s at line #%d\n", __FILE__,__LINE__-9);
            exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
         }

    return EXIT_SUCCESS;
}

And that's how C is supposed to be used. If you're trying to accumulate arbitrarily long strings in memory without doing anything with them, you're using the wrong language. Maybe you want a text file. You can do that with a shell redirect.

use std::io::{self, Write};

fn main() -> io::Result<()> {
    let fp = io::stdin();
    let mut m = String::with_capacity(10);

    fp.read_line(&mut m)?;
    println!("{}", m);
    Ok(())
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90693891
It's a namespace. You don't want to put everything in the same top level namespace. That would be retarded and cause potential name collisions in the future. So we have std as the top level namespace, and then io as a namespace under that for all functions, traits, and types related to input and output.

>>90693898
It wouldn't be very useful to provide a function in the Rust standard library that does exactly the same as the Python "input" function, since it's not very generalizable. We could make a crate with a similar function though. It might look like
use std::io::{self, Write}

pub fn input(prompt: &str) -> io::Result<String> {
    let mut line = String::new();
    let fp = io::stdin();

    print!("{}", prompt);
    io::stdout().flush()?;
    fp.read_line(&mut line)?;
    Ok(line)
}


And then users could write one liners with such a library if need be.
fn main() -> io::Result<()> {
    let m = input("input string : ")?;
    println!("{}", m); 
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90693914
Printing *formatted* strings is a complex task that demands sophisticated and complex tools. The solution C offers involves variadic functions with format strings that are parsed at runtime. This turned out to be a goddamn security disaster. Calling printf(any_user_supplied_string) is asking for memory corruption because some idiot thought %n was a feature that was necessary. On top of this, the printf/scanf family of functions don't support custom formatting for custom data types.

Compared to C, C++ has a better solution in cin and cout. But you cucks complained about operator overloading with this shit. But it's a solution that's extensible and more secure than printf. Technically, it is possible to implement cin and cout in Rust. You don't even need macros. But you know what? Fuck you. Macros make things nicer. You can have format strings, and they get parsed at compile time. Using cin/cout gets a little ugly when you want to have complex formatting since you have to pass in formatter objects to the stream, but macros allow one to hide that shit from the programmer.

Macros are literally the best solution for the problem.

Arch Installation Guide:
parted /dev/sda mklabel msdos
parted /dev/sda mkpart primary ext2 2048s 100%
mkfs.ext3 /dev/sda1
mount /dev/sda1 /mnt
pacstrap /mnt base plasma-meta linux-lts grub dhcpcd

systemctl enable sddm dhcpcd

passwd
exit

Arch Uninstallation Guide
arch-chroot /mnt
passwd -d root
rm /boot/grub/grub.cfg
systemctl disable sddm dhcpcd
pacman -R base plasma-meta linux-lts dhcpcd grub
exit
umount /mnt
wipefs -a /dev/sda1
wipefs -a /dev/sda

posts.com:
I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you’re referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I’ve recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called “Linux”, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project. There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use.

Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine’s resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called “Linux” distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90644294
i use it on my laptop because its a more keyboard focused workflow. not being able to put windows on eachother makes it less cluttered and you can ut stuff side by side real quick. then you have multiple workspaces you switch between. once you learn couple binds ou can manage a bunch of windows quicker than alt tabbing or clicking around. its a bit tricky to set up for multiple monitors and some programs look silly splitting half the screen

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90644294
well for one, keybindings are usually easier to set up than in floating WMs or DEs, so memorization is kind of a non-issue if you use your own.
two, you can still make windows float in most tiling WMs. it doesnt need to be completely keyboard controlled like you think.
at least in bspwm, you can also set certain programs to automatically float on launch, but i never use it. i dont mind hitting one more key to make something float.
the main reason i use one is because whenever i use a floating wm i put every window next to each other anyway, so its really convenient when it does it for me

>>90671103
Distro: Arch
Window manager: BSPWM
Keybindings handler: SXHKD
Terminal: Kitty
Browser: Firefox
Audio management: Keybinding-defined and Pavucontrol
Music player: CMUS
Video player: MPV
Launcher: Rofi (abuse this, you can do A LOT with it)
Editor: Neovim (the basics take an hour to learn, and from there, you only learn more)
Wallpaper setting: Feh
Graphical file manager: PCManFM

As you install all of the software, put the commands you use into a Bash script so that if you ever reinstall, you can just run the script and have everything you need installed again. Make sure you back up your configs.
It takes a while to get a good workflow going, but once you do, everything becomes so much easier and more convenient.

I'll probably end up documenting the less known stuff about KDE in its entirety when I have the sanity and time to do so.
