posts.com:
>What's the best game route to take in Dark Souls?

There isn't really a "best" game route in Dark Souls, as much of the game's appeal comes from the freedom it gives players to explore and progress through the game at their own pace. However, here is a general outline of one way you could approach your first playthrough:

1. Begin by making your way through the tutorial area, Firelink Shrine, and the cemetery.
2. Defeat the undead dragon in the Undead Burg, then make your way to the Bell of Awakening in the Undead Parish and ring it.
3. From there, you can either choose to head to the Lower Undead Burg and defeat the Capra Demon, or explore the rest of the Undead Parish and defeat the giant in the church to obtain the Lordvessel.
4. If you choose the latter option, you can then progress through Anor Londo and defeat the bosses there to obtain the Lordvessel.
5. Once you have the Lordvessel, you can then choose to either progress through Blighttown and defeat Quelaag, or make your way through the Darkroot Basin and defeat Sif to obtain the Covenant of Artorias.
6. Once you have either the Lordvessel or the Covenant of Artorias, you can then progress through Sen's Fortress and Anor Londo to defeat the final bosses and complete the game.

Again, this is just one way you could approach your first playthrough of Dark Souls. The game gives you a lot of freedom to explore and make your own path, so feel free to deviate from this route if you want to.

I think the work Godot has done is truly impressive. They have built a decent general purpose engine with a fraction of the resources Unity or Unreal have. Unfortunately, they are focused on catering towards the inexperienced devs, and I doubt a lot of decent projects will come out of it.

Take for example their scripting language, GDScript. It is very very difficult to scale and manage and codebase with it as it lacks a lot of features any modern language has. And performance is terrible. Its only selling point is that it is very quick to develop in it. Then, they have this in-built IDE which is again far behind anything else, or just simply VS Code. Lots of efforts wasted in there. But the community is strangely zealous towards it, you simply CANNOT criticize GDScript. C# and their GDExtension stuff are second class citizens and make you jump through hoops to solve issues that should not be there. At which point anyway, why not use Unity or Unreal?

Then in general, the engine fails when you start to demand things out of it. I tried to code some Vampire Survivors-like clone (just a prototype, mind you), which you would think is a simple endeavor. Yet the naive approach using their node system became unplayable with just 150 entities. Using all the low-level systems and optimizations, the limit was 600. This is just a simplified boids-like simulation, still without things a real world app would require, which would make it slower. I was about to write myself the entire collision code in C++ when I thought "fuck it, it's not worth it". Meanwhile in Unity you are talking several thousands with the naive approach, probably tens of thousands if you go hard at it. And there are other examples when you quickly find yourself having to go around the engine for basic shit.

I wish them all the best, but if I were to do any serious project, even as an amateur, I would not consider it.

I have been using the Godot engine to create a 2D game, a clone of Vampire Survivors. While I have been generally impressed with the capabilities of the engine, I have encountered performance issues during development.

In an effort to optimize my game, I have tried a number of techniques such as reducing draw calls and using low poly sprites. I have also enabled multithreaded rendering and used the built-in profiler to identify any bottlenecks. Despite these efforts, I have still experienced frame rate drops in certain areas of the game.

I believe that the Godot engine is a powerful tool for creating 2D games, but it may not be the best choice for more demanding projects. While it has certainly improved in recent years, there is still room for improvement in terms of performance.

On the other hand, the Unity engine is a consistently reliable and high-performing choice for game development. Its robust feature set and strong community support make it a top choice for many developers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90682963
I understand your enthusiasm for the Unity engine, but I have to disagree with your assessment of the Godot engine.

I have been using Godot for several of my projects and have found it to be a reliable and high-performing choice for game development. Its simple interface and intuitive tools make it easy to use, even for beginners. I have not encountered any significant performance issues in my projects, and the engine has proven to be quite productive.

I understand that the Unity engine has a large feature set and a strong community, but I believe that the simplicity and reliability of the Godot engine make it a strong choice for many developers. Its focus on performance and productivity make it stand out in the crowded game engine market.

In silverblue /home symlinks to /var/home, and is mutable. >>90678804
Some Ikea products are better than others, and most Ikea products can be made to be long-lasting and durable through some very minor/cheap modifications, as long as they are used reasonably. Wife and I both used Ikea tables as computer desks for about 6 years, including disassembling and moving them to 4 different places. At the end they were still functional when we resold them. I had no problem loading them up with computer stuff, but I would never stand on them.

If you want something you can stand on, spend a shitload for high quality solid wood, find one of those indestructible metal desks from the 80s, or buy two commercial metal filing cabinets and put a solid wood countertop on them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90679259
If you want to use them for a table for modest loads they are fine and can last pretty much forever. One of the key principles behind Ikea is that everything is engineered - by engineers - to be just as strong as it needs to be, so I wouldn't stand on them. If you want an indestructible system that you can match to a different top, get metal filing cabinets.

FWIW I had adjustable legs for my table and the adjustment feature wasn't even strong enough to hold up the table by itself, so I had to cut wooden dowels to stick inside the legs to hold them at the length I wanted.

> hardware backstory
I've got a lot of gear, so I'll try to keep it short:

- Athlon 64 eMachines: curb find (~2012), using as a Windows XP rig (previously pictured)

- Cisnet: found in the trash (late 2022), using as a Windows 98 rig (next to the eMachine)

- Core 2 Quad: $4 at a thrift store (late 2022), installed Fedora for testing, fate to be determined

- 266MHz Athlon K6 IBM Aptiva: $5 at a garage sale (~2010), in storage

- AT&T 6300 8086, white box 386SX, Packard Bell 386SX, Panasonic 386DX - bought the pile for $20 (~2010). Got the white box and Packard Bell working, never got around to the other two. First time installing DOS and configuring a sound card from scratch. In storage.

- Motherboards: AthlonXP from my highschool rig (~2003), Athlon 1GHz from a curb find I gutted (~2005), Pentium 100MHz from a thrift store (~2009). Most history with highschool mobo lugging a desktop+CRT to play Unreal Tournament (original) over 100Mbps for LAN parties.

- "Main" rig (picured): I worked for a electronics recycler during highschool. Probably considered child labor looking back on it, lol. I picked up this case, I don't remember what was inside... Pentium II or later since it's an (early) ATX. I've probably cycled half a dozen builds through it, but currently it has a Ryzen 3900X. The CDROM and floppy drives are not connected but were functional at the time they were pulled from the first computer that was "mine": a 486 100MHz w/ 16MB RAM (~1999).

Probably a dozen other systems I can't think of at the moment...

>>90695999
fuck those automated installers and weird python scripts just boot into the iso and

loadkeys <your country code here, i.e., us/uk>
timedatectl status (then timedatectl set-ntp true if the reported time is incorrect)
gdisk /dev/sdX# > press o > confirm
cfdisk /dev/sdX#
cryptsetup luksFormat /dev/sdX#
cryptsetup open /dev/mapper/sdX# cryptroot
mkfs.ext4 /dev/mapper/cryptroot
mkfs.fat -F32 -n "EFI" /dev/sdX#
pacstrap -K /mnt base linux linux-firmware
genfstab -U /mnt > /mnt/etc/fstab
arch-chroot /mnt
passwd root
useradd -m user
passwd user
ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/Region/City /etc/localtime
hwclock --systohc
echo "LANG=en_US.UTF-8" > /etc/locale.conf
echo "KEYMAP=us" > /etc/vconsole.conf
echo "hostname" > /etc/hostname
echo "bgrt_disable BOOT_IMAGE=/efi/arch-linux.efi root=UUID=<insert /dev/mapper/cryptroot UUID here> rw cryptdevice=UUID=<insert LUKS container uuid here>:cryptroot root=/dev/mapper/cryptroot loglevel=3 quiet" > /etc/kernel/cmdline
Now set the module order in mkinitcpio.conf if you intend to use it (keyboard & keymap after autodetect & encrypt after block), do whatever additional configuration you need or want for your system
and finally pacman -S networkmanager
systemctl enable networkmanager

And reboot. After entering the disks password you should boot straight into a console with internet access.

overperforming

over- (prefix)
word-forming element meaning variously "above; highest; across; higher in power or authority; too much; above normal; outer; beyond in time, too long,"
In some of its uses, moreover, over is a movable element, which can be prefixed at will to almost any verb or adjective of suitable sense, as freely as an adjective can be placed before a substantive or an adverb before an adjective.

perform (verb)
to go through or execute in the proper, customary, or established manner:
to enact (a play, part, etc.), as on the stage, in movies, or on television.

-ing (suffix)
a suffix of nouns formed from verbs, expressing the action of the verb or its result, product, material, etc. (the art of building; a new building; cotton wadding). It is also used to form nouns from words other than verbs (offing; shirting).

over-perform-ing:
to surpass in excellence of performance; do better than.

This is not true.
1. Massive Language Models with MoE switches perform better than Large Language Models without MoEs. (Take a look at switch C) https://arxiv.org/pdf/2101.03961.pdf
>In deep learning, models typically reuse the same parameters for all inputs. Mixture of Experts (MoE) models defy this and instead select different parameters for each incoming example. The result is a sparsely-activated model—with an outrageous number of parameters—but a constant computational cost.

2. Additionally, fine-tuning LaMDA made it significantly better:
Pic related is the 2b, 8b and 137b parameter LaMDA models before and after fine tuning
Notice how they get considerably less unhinged? Considerably less insane? This is the difference between being able to use it with 24/7 supervision and oversight vs letting it teach your 12 year olds geometry and algebra unsupervised.

>>90693273
It's a language model anon, sometimes it just doesn't understand things, maybe there's not enough chimp behavior in the training set or something.

That does give me a hypothesis about the "are you ready?" stuff. LLMs can generate more tokens forever, so CAI had to figure out how to pick a decent ending point for the bot responses. I figure, maybe it stops when there's a sharp increase in entropy (that is, its confidence in the next token drops a lot). That would tend to be the end of sentences, especially things like "are you ready?" which could lead into anything. If sudden uncertainty stops the text it would explain a lot.

I don't think it's the filter though, desu I think the filter might be a godsend for them because it stops people from noticing how dumb the bots really are. It has this addictive gacha-like quality that spurs people on thinking they might defeat it next time. I guess we'll find out eventually once there's a runnable open model.

which reveals two other problems.

https://github.com/swindlesmccoop/SLUTS
Just starting a new one to share my own script
#!/bin/sh
# A script to automatically split an image into segments and prompt to remove unwanted images when done.
# example:    divideImage file.jpg 5x4
# Written for use with exiftool, bc, imagemagick, and nsxiv.
segment=$( (    exiftool "$1" | sed '/^Image Size/!d;s/^Image Size *: //'
    echo $2
) | sed 's/x/\n/' | pr -2 -s" / " -t | bc | sed -z 's/\n/x/')

exiftool -all= "$1"
convert "$1" -crop $segment "${1%.*}-%02d.jpg"
rm "${1}_original"
nsxiv -to . | xargs rm -v

Pic related is part of the result of my script.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90688865
You are over-complicating this OP.

So long as they are on separate drives, they will play nice. Set up windows on a drive, and Linux on the other. Setup GRUB to have Linux as a boot option, and Widows as a boot option, via chainloading (esentially you point grub towards the windows bootloader). Make sure the BIOS is set to boot the Linux drive first.

It is easy, less wear and tear, and perfectly secure. Windows won't fuck with GRUB so long as both GRUB and the Windows bootloader are not on the same drive.

>>90689228
>>90689284
The comparison to make is not "Latent vs GAN", the comparison to make is "Latent vs GAN vs original small image". As the other anon says, he's not making any comments about which upscaler is best for your specific use case, he's just pointing out that you're underestimating the GANs which sometimes really are the "best" option over latent. More detail is not automatically better, latent forces you to have more than about 0.6 denoising which means you're losing fidelity to the base image which might have minor features you value highly. The best way to demonstrate this to yourself is to generate a few dozen pics with hires fix turned off, pick a few you really like, then regenerate them with hires fix doubling them on Latent and on your upscaler of choice. The Latent ones will still look super nice and detailed, sure, but you'll find that since it departs significantly from the base image it sometimes chews up features you like. Also, the way it works on such fine detail means you're overly likely to end up with curly hair, intricate baroque style, etc without having asked for it. Yes, it's good, it's my favourite, but using a GAN upscaler also has its place (and works great down at 0.3 denoise or even lower)
>pic related, see how obsessive latent gets with the buttons/belt loops? this issue is demonstrably repeatable, it's not a flat upgrade over GAN

>>90689544
>>90689572
It's literally just the tech from some instagram type face app for enhancing photos, 100% intended for selfies etc. So yeah it'll wreck anime and it's mixed at best even on realistic/concept art drawings. My recommendation is leave it off even for photos, it's available in the Extras tab to apply with finer control choosing between GFPGAN and Codeformers and applying a weight of each if you really want, that'll also help you demonstrate to yourself how crazily it wrecks anime gens

>>90690007
as an addendum, the pinstripe shorts here also demonstrate really well the *strength* of Latent upscaler, where you can tell the other ones are working from an upscaled base image so the "pin"stripes are a tiny bit thicker, while the latent upscale works innately from the upscaled latent space so it's able to start from scratch at the higher res making pinstripes as small as it can for the greater resolution

>>90690024
High res fix wasn't changed except for a minor change to firstpass aspect ratio freedom, everything else is just a GUI change that makes it simpler. If you think it's worse now the issue is you never understood it properly in the first place, the good news is that you actually live in a world where hires fix has been improved so now you get to be happy again. Set the resolution to what you used to set the "first pass" setting to (e.g. 512x640 or something like that), set the upscale number to 2 to double it so your final result will be 1024x1280, and pick any upscaler you like

Have used it for a month, my experience was that as people say you get "beautiful" outputs trivially with any prompt of a few words, it's hard to drag it away from the repetitive cheesy reddit house style but if you can do so you can get stuff more aesthetic than the "peak" of stablediffusion (but again with far less user input into defining it). So painful to do that it's not worth the effort though, since 90% of the time your prompt either goes too far and breaks it into garbage, or doesn't go far enough and yet again generates western concept art of a portrait shot of an attractive slightly-offbeat woman standing in front of a background with a circular feature ringing her. The one thing I found very useful was image prompting, you can give it an image url (or multiple images) as a "word" in the prompt and it's nearly equivalent to having trained a dreambooth model in 10 seconds, very convenient for some mashup stuff I needed to do. Also, I cancelled my subscription near the end of the first month on account of aforementioned issue with MJ being ugly shite, and it fully refunded me all $50 or whatever lol. didnt expect that.

I have not messed with SDv2 too much, I just don't like the texture of the outputs (except cityscapes, it's better at that). What's apparent is that with the prompting it's very specific. Both with SDv2 and WDv1.4, though the former is more sentence focused while with the latter you should stick with the commas/booru tagging. You can play around with this https://huggingface.co/spaces/pharma/CLIP-Interrogator for examples. The issue (other than removing and cucking certain stuff) is that it often misinterprets a prompt, it's too precise in the wrong way for certain inputs which results in you having to use a negative prompt to guide it away from the issue and change its focus.

>>90690258
>txt2video will reach current txt2img state
There's no way that's happening this year. txt2img is already pushing the limits of what we can train for less than hundreds of millions with modern computational power, as well as the limits of what can run on modern consumer hardware. Even the biggest players have nothing close to the computation or data that we'd need to train or run networks that can operate on proper latent encodings of videos. Give it 6-7 more years.

>but something even more external and random like my house's power
It does not imply that at all. The most likely explanation is cracking or corroded solder balls or pads on your GPU or memory chips. Bad electrical connections can sometimes have a random character, working for some time and then failing, and then resetting when thermal cycled as you turn the PC off. Could also be the CPU. You can use looong stress tests to prove the CPU and memory are good, leaving only the GPU.

>>90692731
If you go to Settings > Stable Diffusion > "Ignore selected VAE for stable diffusion checkpoints that have hteir own .vae.pt next to them" ->> Turn that off.

Then you can pick the vae you want specifically and use one for any/every model.

You can also add the vae drop-down to the quick settings bar at the top by doing:

Settings > User Interface > "Quicksettings list" and enter "sd_vae" (without the quote marks)
